item.title: Behind the Masks in Ukraine, Many Faces of Rebellion
item.description: A deeper look at the rebels in Ukraine offers a murky picture of their aims, motivations and connections. They appear to be Ukrainians, but they have deep ties to and affinity for Russia.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian militiamen at their base in Slovyansk, Ukraine, last week. A deeper look at the rebels offers a murky picture of their aims, motivations and connections. The rebels appear to be Ukrainians, but they have deep ties to and affinity for Russia.

item.title: Ukraine Presses Rebels as Events Spiral in East
item.description: Even as European military observers held as suspected NATO spies were released Saturday, Russia cited bloody street violence in Odessa as proof that Ukraine could no longer protect its citizens.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rebel checkpoint Saturday as Ukrainian troops pressed their assault on separatists in the east.

item.title: More Than 2,000 Feared Dead in Landslide in Afghanistan
item.description: President Hamid Karzai declared Sunday a national day of mourning and ordered all flags flown at half-staff.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: 20 Are Held and Curfew Is Imposed After Attacks on Muslims in India
item.description: Police say the attacks were carried out by militants with an armed insurgent group that has been agitating for a separate state for decades.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Relatives of victims mourned at a burial ground at Narayanguri village, in the northeastern Indian state of Assam, on Saturday.

item.title: In Latest Government Shuffle, North Korean Leader Removes No. 2 Official From Top Posts
item.description: Seen less frequently accompanying the leader in his public activities, it remained unclear whether Vice Marshal Choe Ryong-hae was removed from other key positions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: For the past two years, Vice Marshal Choe Ryong-hae, left, has been head of the General Political Bureau of the North Korean People’s Army.

item.title: Death Stalks Muslims as Myanmar Cuts Off Aid
item.description: Myanmar’s Buddhist-led government has targeted the Rohingya people, depriving them of liberties even as it trumpets democratic reforms.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: World Briefing: Ethiopia: Student Protesters Killed in Clashes With Police
item.description: At least 11 students have been killed in violent clashes with Ethiopian police in a region that has long been the scene of a secessionist movement, the government said late Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Police Revise Number of Kidnapped Students
item.description: The number of kidnapped schoolgirls missing in Nigeria has been revised to 276, up by more than 30 from a previous estimate, the police said late Thursday, adding that the actual number abducted by Islamic extremists on April 14 was more than 300.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Publicist Sentenced for Assaults on Women
item.description: Max Clifford, the influential British publicist best known for managing the reputations of celebrities, was sentenced Friday to eight years in prison for a string of indecent assaults on four women.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Merkel Signals That Tension Persists Over U.S. Spying
item.description: At a White House meeting meant to mend fences, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said it was too soon to return to “business as usual” with the United States following disclosures that the N.S.A had eavesdropped on her phone calls.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany after a news conference in the Rose Garden on Friday.

item.title: Juan Formell, 71, Cuban Dance-Band Leader, Dies
item.description: Mr. Formell, the founder of Los Van Van, created an infectious, popular hybrid of Afro-Cuban music that influenced salsa performers like Ruben Blades.
item.dc:creator: By LARRY ROHTER
item.media:description: Juan Formell accepting a lifetime achievement award in 2013.

item.title: Plying Social Media, Chinese Workers Grow Bolder in Exerting Clout
item.description: A shrinking labor pool in China has shifted more bargaining power to workers, and a mass walkout illustrated their willingness to use it.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Signs supporting shoe factory workers were left outside a Nike shop in Hong Kong. The signs say “Blood and sweat factory.”

item.title: Accident Leads to Scrutiny of Oil Sand Production
item.description: A relatively minor leak last year has led regulators in Alberta to re-examine production that uses steam under pressure to separate oil from subterranean sands.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:description: Workers from Canadian Natural Resources, an oil company, cleaning up the marshy Primrose site in Alberta, Canada, in August.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Ignore Northern Ireland’s Ghosts
item.description: Too many victims’ families still await justice.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE CADWALLADER

item.title: World Briefing : Central African Republic: Gunmen Kill at Least 15 in a Border Town
item.description: Gunmen killed about 15 people, including children, in an attack on a town in the Central African Republic near the border with Chad, a local official and aid workers said Friday.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Ukrainians Strike Rebel-Held City as Fighting Spreads
item.description: Ukrainian military and police forces resumed their effort to retake Slovyansk, and violence erupted in port city of Odessa on the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-Russian villager argued with Ukrainian soldiers after troops were blocked by residents at a checkpoint in Andreyevka.

item.title: South Sudan Will Talk With Rebels, Kerry Says
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said the president, Salva Kiir, had promised to take “forceful steps” to carry out a cease-fire pact he and his former vice president, Riek Machar, signed in January.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Salva Kiir Mayardit of South Sudan, right, greeted U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry in Juba, South Sudan, on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Deadly Clash in Benghazi
item.description: Gunmen attacked a security forces headquarters in Libya’s eastern city of Benghazi early Friday, killing nine people and wounding 24, the authorities said. The government blamed Ansar al-Shariah, an Islamic extremist group accused of being behind the attack on an American diplomatic post in Benghazi.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Deadly Attacks Heighten Tension in Egypt
item.description: Bombings in Sinai and Cairo raised concerns of a renewed wave of violence ahead of a presidential election this month.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Egyptian security forces investigated the site of a bomb blast at a security checkpoint in Cairo on Friday.

item.title: Sinn Fein Leader’s Time in Jail Is Extended, as Party Sees Political Motives by Police
item.description: Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, remains under questioning about a gruesome 1972 murder, as his political party said that the police were playing politics.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:description: Northern Ireland justice minister, David Ford, speaking outside the jail where Jerry Adams is being held, said that he had seen no evidence “of policing being operated on a political basis.”

item.title: First U.S. Case of MERS Virus Is Found in Indiana Man Who Visited Mideast
item.description: The virus, which is similar to SARS and has killed more than 100 people in the Middle East, was found in a health care worker who recently returned from Saudi Arabia.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Osama Alomar Pursues His Literary Ambitions in Exile
item.description: Though he drives a cab in Chicago six days a week to make ends meet, the exiled writer Osama Alomar has hopes of becoming a distinct American literary voice, as well as a Syrian one.
item.dc:creator: By LARRY ROHTER
item.media:credit: Nathan Weber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Syrian writer Osama Alomar in his cab in the Chicago suburbs.

item.title: Opinion: Revenge, My Lovely
item.description: Our desire for payback isn’t just a pointless instinct. It exemplifies our capacity for abstract thought.
item.dc:creator: By JO NESBO

item.title: Hundreds of Afghans Are Killed in Landslides
item.description: As many as 2,500 people were said to be missing in the disaster, one of the worst to hit the country in at least a decade.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HARIS KAKAR
item.media:description: People searched for survivors Friday after a hillside softened by weeks of rain gave way above the northeastern village of Abi Barak in Badakhshan Province.

item.title: A Heinous Crime, Secret Histories and a Sinn Fein Leader’s Arrest
item.description: The arrest of Gerry Adams on Wednesday came after officials subpoenaed interviews from a Boston College oral history project whose subjects had been promised confidentiality.
item.dc:creator: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
item.media:description: Jean McConville, left, with three of her 10 children. She was abducted in 1972 and murdered.
